book-title-group.subtitle: Religion and Culture in a Quebec Parish, 1736-1901

abstract.p: There are many analyses of Tractarianism – a nineteenth-century form of Anglicanism that emphasized its Catholic origins – but how did people in the colonies react to the High Church movement? Beating against the Wind, a study in nineteenth-century vernacular spirituality, emphasizes the power of faith on a shifting frontier in a transatlantic world. Focusing on people living along the Newfoundland and Labrador coast, Calvin Hollett presents a nuanced perspective on popular resistance to the colonial emissary Bishop Edward Feild and his spiritual regimen of order, silence, and solemnity. Whether by outright opposing Bishop Feild, or by simply ignoring his wishes and views, or by brokering a hybrid style of Gothic architecture, the people of Newfoundland and Labrador demonstrated their independence in the face of an attempt at hierarchical ascendency upon the arrival of Tractarianism in British North America. Instead, they continued to practise evangelical Anglicanism and participate in Methodist revivals, and thereby negotiated a popular Protestantism, one often infused with the spirituality of other seafarers from Nova Scotia and New England. abstract.p: In his well-known mid-nineteenth-century painting,Breaking Lent, the Dutch-born artist Cornelius Krieghoff (1815–1872) depicted half a dozen members of a nineteenth-century habitant family at table in their rudely furnished cabin. They are consuming a forbidden Lenten meal of meat during the Catholic Church’s forty-day period of obligatory fasting and abstinence before Easter. Into the room strides the formidable Father Brassard, the parish priest in Longueuil, on the south shore of the St Lawrence River across from Montréal, where Krieghoff himself was living between 1845 and 1848. Almost in the same breath as he described the independent nature of the habitants in 1830, the surgeon and author Pierre de Sales Laterrière (1789–1834) argued that the influence of Catholicism over the habitants was largely positive or at least harmless. Laterrière argued that the Church did not exercise untrammelled power or that “a complete subjection of the people has not taken place, and a grovelling superstition and furious bigotry” had not been introduced, even if many were mildly “superstitious”:
It may be said, and perhaps with truth, that the Canadian population are, for the most part, superstitious; but

Important as it was in the life of the parish, institutional Catholicism did not hold uncontested sway over the spiritual terrain of St-Joseph. A popular metaphysical world that constituted a significant sector of the mental universe of the habitants existed beside it, presenting both an alternative to and a reinforcement of the Church’s own teachings. Québec’s customary period of winter sociability, thetemps des fêtes, lasting from Christmas to the start of Lent, is the ideal period for examining the link that many parish priests drew between the traditional celebrations of their parishioners and the difficulties that the Church encountered in attempting to transform them into more submissive Catholics. Studying the forms and meanings of this sociability enables us to understand how the habitants implicitly asserted some of the important secular values of their traditional way of life in the face of explicit and repeated clerical disapproval. title-group.subtitle: “On danse pour le plaisir de danser”

abstract.p: In their annual reports to their superiors in Québec City during the last half of the nineteenth century, the curés in St-Joseph continuously lamented their inability to reduce, let alone prohibit, what they felt were the large number of evening parties, drinking, and dancing in the parish. The Reverend David Martineau noted in his 1854 report that dances andveilléeswere “still too frequent.”¹ His successor for the period 1856–68, James Nelligan, left no parish reports, and it is not possible to say whether such celebrations diminished, though it is unlikely.
